section.title: Alternatives
section.p: Maybe it's unwise to advertise your competitors but we believe competition is good and we have the best support reading and write Excel workbooks currently available. This however does not purport to be a complete list.

tr.td: Reading, calculating standard and VBA functions with Java at runtime.
An alternative to this project is to buy the $5000 per server installation.
Give up XML and write Visual Basic code on a Microsoft Windows based Environment or output in Microsoft's beta and primarily undocumented XML for office format.
Frequently unavailable. Little currently known about it's capabilities.
This effort supports Gnumeric and Excel, however the Excel part is done using POI anyway.
Provides decent support for reading Excel.
ODBC offers a somewhat wierd method for using Excel.
Commercial library for reading, modifying and writing Excel spreadsheets. Not cheap but certainly a lot more affordable than Formula 1. No idea as to it's quality.
Uses DCOM to an Excel instance on a windows machine.
There are a number of perl and C libraries, however none of them are consistent.

VistaJDBC driver works with both StarOffice and Excel spreadsheets and can access data using standard SQL statements without any API programming. VistaJDBC also implemented ability to choose by not just rows and columns but by specific cells, ranges of cells, etc.

This library outputs a simple CSV file, in which cells can contain numbers or text. You could output a CSV file without its help, but it gives a little more readability/structure to the code, and could be extended to handle more complexity. When you invoke one of these JSP pages from your browser, you open up an Excel spreadsheet. There's no formatting, worksheets, or anything fancy like that. So it's not strictly a competitor but it does the job.
